Linked List Implementation 2

`[ ]` Why should you declare all the variables of a class outside the init?  
`[>]` Maybe to declare all variable, even the ones not used at `__init__`.

```{python}
class Node:
    """
    An object for storing a single node of a linked list.
    Models two attributes - data and the link to the next node in the list
    """
    data = None
    
    def __init__(self, data):
        self.data = data
        
        
    def __repr__(self):
        # repr means representation
        return "<Node data: %s>" % self.data
```

```{python}
class LinkedList:
    
    head = None
    
    def __init__(self):
        self.head = None
        
    def __repr__(self):
        
        current = self.head
        arrList = []
        
        while current != None:
            arrList.append(current.data)
            current = current.next_node
       
        arrstring = ']->['.join([f'{node}' for node in arrList])
        return f"<LinkedList2> count:{len(arrList)} \n[{arrstring}]"
        
    def add(self,data):
        
        if self.head == None:
            self.head = Node(data)
        
        else:
            current = self.head
            
            while current.next_node != None:
                current = current.next_node
                
            current.next_node = Node(data)
        
```
